user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of post_iterator:
```c
static enum MHD_Result
post_iterator (void *cls,
               enum MHD_ValueKind kind,
               const char *key,
               const char *filename,
               const char *content_type,
               const char *transfer_encoding,
               const char *data, uint64_t off, size_t size)
{
  struct Request *request = cls;
  struct Session *session = request->session;
  (void) kind;              /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */
  (void) filename;          /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */
  (void) content_type;      /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */
  (void) transfer_encoding; /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */

  if (0 == strcmp ("DONE", key))
  {
    fprintf (stdout,
             "Session `%s' submitted `%s', `%s'\n",
             session->sid,
             session->value_1,
             session->value_2);
    return MHD_YES;
  }
  if (0 == strcmp ("v1", key))
  {
    if (off >= sizeof(session->value_1) - 1)
      return MHD_YES; /* Discard extra data */
    if (size + off >= sizeof(session->value_1))
      size = (size_t) (sizeof (session->value_1) - off - 1); /* crop extra data */
    memcpy (&session->value_1[off],
            data,
            size);
    session->value_1[size + off] = '\0';
    return MHD_YES;
  }
  if (0 == strcmp ("v2", key))
  {
    if (off >= sizeof(session->value_2) - 1)
      return MHD_YES; /* Discard extra data */
    if (size + off >= sizeof(session->value_2))
      size = (size_t) (sizeof (session->value_2) - off - 1); /* crop extra data */
    memcpy (&session->value_2[off],
            data,
            size);
    session->value_2[size + off] = '\0';
    return MHD_YES;
  }
  fprintf (stderr,
           "Unsupported form value `%s'\n",
           key);
  return MHD_YES;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No controlling expressions in this function are invariant. Each conditional depends on runtime data or variables, so they do not violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3:

- if (0 == strcmp ("DONE", key)) — strcmp uses the runtime value of key; result is not a compile-time constant.
- if (0 == strcmp ("v1", key)) and if (0 == strcmp ("v2", key)) — same reasoning.
- if (off >= sizeof(session->value_1) - 1) and if (size + off >= sizeof(session->value_1)) (and the analogous checks for value_2) — these comparisons involve the runtime variables off and size; sizeof(...) is a compile-time constant but the overall expressions depend on runtime values and therefore are not invariant.

There are no loops with constant controlling expressions (e.g., while(1) or for(;;)) and no do-while constructs that would fall under the listed exceptions. The (void) casts are not controlling expressions. Therefore no code fragments need investigation for Rule 14.3 in this function.
